paper_metadata.title: Paclitaxel increases axonal localization and vesicular trafficking of Nav1.7

theory_synthesis.description: Cytoskeletal state, particularly microtubule stabilization and post-translational modifications, tunes ion-channel trafficking to axons, thereby setting spike thresholds and the potential temporal precision required for large-scale synchrony. Inflammatory milieu further amplifies this trafficking control, implying state-dependent gating of timing-relevant excitability.

1.claim_text: Nav channel density and kinetics influence spike initiation precision and phase-locking across oscillatory bands.

direct_quotes.quote: Human and rat dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons become hyperexcitable after treatment with PTX, due to increased expression of several types of ion channels, including the voltage-gated sodium (Nav) channel Nav1.7.
Treatment with PTX increased levels of endogenous Nav1.7 mRNA and current density in dorsal root ganglion neurons.
Low concentrations of PTX increase surface channel expression and vesicular flux (number of vesicles per axon).

1.interpretation: By increasing Nav1.7 mRNA, current density, and axonal surface levels, PTX raises Nav channel availability at peripheral terminals, lowering spike threshold and shaping spike initiation. While oscillatory phase-locking was not measured, the established role of Nav1.7 as a threshold channel implies that its density modulates the precision of spike onset, a prerequisite for precise phase relationships in oscillations.
1.limitations: Data are from DRG sensory neurons; no direct measurements of spike-time precision or phase-locking across oscillatory bands were performed.

6.claim_text: Microtubule and MAP stability maintain synaptic organization and influence spike-time precision.

direct_quotes.quote: PTX is a microtubule stabilizer that binds to the inner lumen of the microtubule, promoting microtubule polymerization and stabilizing against depolymerization.
We demonstrate concentration and time-dependent effects of PTX on vesicular trafficking and membrane localization of Nav1.7 in real-time in sensory axons.

Using these new methods, we demonstrated fast microtubule-based vesicular Nav1.7 transport in sensory axons, which was disrupted by treatment with the microtubule depolymerizing drug nocodazole. Thus, we would expect that PTX-induced changes to microtubules would impact Nav1.7 axonal transport.

At low concentrations (25 nM PTX), we found increased levels of Nav1.7 at the surface in distal axons at 24 and 48 h, which is accompanied by an enhancement of vesicular trafficking with increases in both the flux and velocity of Nav1.7-containing vesicles.

6.interpretation: Because PTX stabilizes microtubules, the observed dose-dependent increases (low dose) or decreases (high dose) in Nav1.7 vesicle flux and the increased surface localization at axonal endings show that cytoskeletal stability directly governs ion-channel delivery to functional domains. This trafficking control is a mechanistic route by which microtubules can influence spike initiation timing, and thereby precision, via modulation of the local channel landscape.
6.limitations: The study assesses axonal terminals of DRG neurons rather than central synapses and does not measure spike-time precision directly; MAP-specific mechanisms were discussed but not experimentally dissected.

36.claim_text: Microtubule post-translational modifications (acetylation, detyrosination, polyglutamylation) tune lattice longevity and timing precision.

direct_quotes.quote: Low levels of PTX cause modest microtubule stabilization, while higher concentrations of PTX increase the number of microtubules and cause microtubule bundling.

PTX can affect the post-translational modifications of tubulin, or the compliment of microtubule associated proteins. These modifications can interfere with the affinity of kinesin motors for microtubules, or their ability to navigate the microtubules.

We observed that cultures incubated with 25 nM PTX had more anterogradely moving vesicles per axon (flux) than control axons at all time points... incubation with either 25 nM or 250 nM PTX caused an increase in average anterograde vesicular velocity, even within 6 h.

36.interpretation: The authors explicitly note that PTX alters tubulin post-translational modifications and MAP complement, which in turn modulate kinesin–microtubule interactions and vesicle navigation. The observed changes in vesicle flux/velocity and surface delivery of Nav1.7 are consistent with PTM-dependent tuning of microtubule lattice properties that affect transport dynamics, a plausible route to influence neuronal timing precision via altered channel distribution.
36.limitations: PTMs were not directly measured, nor were timing precision or oscillatory metrics; the PTM mechanism is presented as a plausible explanation rather than experimentally demonstrated in this study.

additional_or_contradictory_insights.finding: Inflammatory mediators synergistically amplify PTX effects on Nav1.7 surface levels and axonal transport.
quotes: After exposure to inflammatory mediators to mimic the inflammatory condition seen during chemotherapy, both Nav1.7 surface levels and vesicular transport are increased for both low and high concentrations of PTX.
An increase in mean fluorescence intensity of Nav1.7 surface labelling in axons treated with IM was seen for all conditions (DMSO, 25 nM PTX, 250 nM PTX) compared to axons not receiving IM.
additional_or_contradictory_insights.relevance: Reveals state-dependent modulation of channel trafficking by inflammatory signaling, suggesting that non-neuronal or milieu factors can gate timing-relevant excitability beyond intrinsic cytoskeletal control.

additional_or_contradictory_insights.finding: Microtubule stabilization has non-linear, dose-dependent effects on transport: low-dose PTX enhances Nav1.7 flux and surface localization, whereas higher dose reduces flux and promotes axonal degeneration.
quotes: Low concentrations of PTX increase surface channel expression and vesicular flux... By contrast, treatment with a higher concentration of PTX decreases vesicular flux.
Retraction bulbs... were seen more frequently with higher concentrations of PTX, as well as increasing over time of incubation.
additional_or_contradictory_insights.relevance: Highlights that cytoskeletal interventions can differentially modulate transport and structural integrity, important for modeling how microtubule-targeting agents affect timing-relevant channel distribution.

additional_or_contradictory_insights.finding: Endogenous Nav1.7 current density increases with PTX, but transfected Halo-Nav1.7 current does not, despite increased trafficking.
quotes: Treatment with PTX increased levels of endogenous Nav1.7 mRNA and current density in dorsal root ganglion neurons. However, the current produced by transfection of dorsal root ganglion neurons with Halo-tag Nav1.7 was not increased after exposure to PTX.
We interpret our data to suggest that the increased axonal vesicular trafficking and surface channels... might be independent of an increased pool of Nav1.7 channels.
additional_or_contradictory_insights.relevance: Separates trafficking/localization control from total channel abundance, indicating multiple regulatory layers that can independently shape excitability and potential timing properties.
